channel.title: Command Help
channel.description:
} if (playerCommand.equals("dzone") && c.isDonator == 1) { if (c.inWild()) c.getPA().startTeleport(3291, 2764, 0, "modern"); c.sendMessage("@whi@Thank You For Donating! Enjoy your Benefits!");
I was trying to make a command for my Donators, yet the command just isn't working? I don't know what wrong with it, I'm not getting any errors etc, the command just doesn't work when you try to use it. [size=18pt]Edit: Fixed, Thanks for all of you who helped :). - Thanks, Lanepker[/size]

item.title: Command Help
item.dc:creator: @Lanepker Lanepker
item.description:
@Lanepker wrote:

So should I post this as the command instead but change the absX to the coords as well as absY?

if(playerCommand.startsWith(""dzone)) { if(c.inWild()) return; c2.teleportToX = absX; c2.teleportToY = absY;

Read full topic

item.title: Command Help
item.dc:creator: @Dan0194 Dan0194
item.description:
@Dan0194 wrote:

[quote=“Scape-JAVA, post:11, topic:539662”][quote author=Vain_ link=topic=658504.msg4404722#msg4404722 date=1391555438]
project insanity divides commands into different methods for player rights. whether or not the command has a check for them, it checks the section first.
[/quote]

What he means is this little portion [sub]&& c.isDonator == 1) [/sub] is an unncessary instance as project insanity’s command class is setup as to where they have methods that check the players rights.

[code]
public static void Commands implements PacketType {
//other crap up here

if(c.playerRights = 0) {
playerCommands(c, playerCommand);
}
if(c.playerRights = 1) {
moderatorCommands(c, playerCommand);
}
if(c.playerRights = 2) {
administratorCommand(c, playerCommand);
}
}
public void playerCommands(Client c, playerCommand) {
//bla
}
public void moderatorCommands(Client c, String playerCommand) {
//bla
}
public void administratorCommands(Client c, String playerCommand) {
//bla
}[/code]

you get the point.[/quote]
You should use abstraction for this.

Read full topic

item.title: Command Help
item.dc:creator: @Scape-JAVA Scape-JAVA
item.description:
@Scape-JAVA wrote:

Vain_:

project insanity divides commands into different methods for player rights. whether or not the command has a check for them, it checks the section first.

What he means is this little portion [sub]&& c.isDonator == 1) [/sub] is an unncessary instance as project insanity’s command class is setup as to where they have methods that check the players rights.

[code]
public static void Commands implements PacketType {
//other crap up here

if(c.playerRights = 0) {
playerCommands(c, playerCommand);
}
if(c.playerRights = 1) {
moderatorCommands(c, playerCommand);
}
if(c.playerRights = 2) {
administratorCommand(c, playerCommand);
}
}
public void playerCommands(Client c, playerCommand) {
//bla
}
public void moderatorCommands(Client c, String playerCommand) {
//bla
}
public void administratorCommands(Client c, String playerCommand) {
//bla
}[/code]

you get the point.

Read full topic

item.title: Command Help
item.dc:creator: @Vain1 Vain_
item.description:
@Vain1 wrote:

project insanity divides commands into different methods for player rights. whether or not the command has a check for them, it checks the section first.

item.title: Command Help
item.dc:creator: @Scape-JAVA Scape-JAVA
item.description:
@Scape-JAVA wrote:

So, from what I see it’s a logic error.

if(playerCommand.startsWith(""dzone)) {
if(c.inWild())
return;
c2.teleportToX = absX;
c2.teleportToY = absY;

If you want a wildy check you need to return it after the check is over to allow the command to continue on, etc.
http://www.dummies.com/how-to/content/java-keywords.html

Read full topic

item.title: Command Help
item.dc:creator: @Lanepker Lanepker
item.description:
@Lanepker wrote:

Pure_:

You have an if check, checking if the player is in the wilderness before teleporting them. I think you meant to check if they aren’t in the wild before teleporting them.

So should I delete if (c.inWild()) ?
